metadata.case_name: Defendants First Party v. Plaintiffs (Successors of Santokhi Jha)

facts.text: Santokhi Jha became owner of the entire raiyati interest in 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza Chhatahara, District of Santhal Parganas.
Santokhi Jha purchased by registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was the raiyat.
Plaintiffs and four defendants (2nd party) are successors in interest of Santokhi Jha.
On May 15, 1935, the lands were sold by 2nd party defendants and plaintiffs 1 to 6 to present appellants (defendants first party).
Plaintiffs' case: No interest passed by 1935 sale deed because raiyati character existed and was inalienable under Regulation III of 1872; transfer fraudulent, collusive, no legal necessity.
Defendants first party pleaded: No fraud or collusion; transfer for legal necessity to pay antecedent debts; lands were bakasht lands of malik, not raiyati on sale date.
Subordinate Judge, Dumka: Sale justified by legal necessity, not fraudulent; land lost raiyati character after Santokhi acquired landlord's interest; dismissed suit.
District Judge, Santhal Parganas: Affirmed trial court findings; suit rightly dismissed.
High Court (Banerjee J.): Raiyati interest continued despite acquisition of landlord's interest; no merger; sale void regarding raiyati interest; allowed plaintiffs' appeal.
Letters Patent Appeal by defendants first party dismissed; High Court certified fit for SC appeal under s.110 CPC and Art.135 Constitution.
First settlement record showed lands held by Santokhi as raiyat; later records showed as bakasht malik.

In 1909 Settlement Objection Case No.41, Santokhi objected to record of rights entry; stated he purchased zamindari interest three years ago, wanted village made khas and jote interest as bakasht malik; approved by Settlement Officer.
Bakasht malik means lands in cultivating possession of owner/landlord, not privileged.

legal_issues.text: If a raiyat of lands in Santhal Parganas acquires entire superior landlord's interest, does raiyati interest cease (merge) or continue?
Whether 1935 sale transferred raiyati interest, given s.27 Regulation III of 1872.
Civil court's jurisdiction vs. exclusive remedy under s.27(3) Regulation III of 1872.

petitioner_arguments.text: After Santokhi acquired Lakhirajdar's interest, he ceased to be raiyat: automatic merger of lesser (raiyati) in greater (landlord) interest; or option exercised to merge.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: English common law merger (Blackstone); equity intention

petitioner_arguments.text: Subsequent record of rights entry (bakasht malik) prevails over earlier raiyati entry; negates raiyati interest.
Settlement Officer's 1909 decision operates as res judicata.
Whether raiyati interest continued is pure question of fact; lower courts found it ceased; High Court could not interfere in second appeal.
Civil court has no jurisdiction; only Deputy Commissioner under s.27(3) Regulation III of 1872.

respondent_arguments.text: Raiyati interest continued despite acquisition of superior interest; no merger; sale void as to raiyati interest under s.27 Reg.III 1872.
Raiyat bound to keep raiyati interest separate due to village community interests in Santhal Parganas.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Santhal Parganas land tenure customs; Settlement Reports

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of merger: Union of interests does not automatically merge; merger only if clear intention; courts look to conduct, benefit, duty to keep separate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Indian law modified English common law; no automatic merger.

court_reasoning.text: Special features in Santhal Parganas: Village community rights, headman duties, policy against alienation of raiyati lands (Govt orders 1887, amendment Reg.III 1872); raiyat has no right to end raiyati interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine of merger difficult to apply; prima facie raiyat must keep interest intact.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence Santokhi intended merger: 1909 objection sought bakasht malik record (cultivation by owner), not negation of raiyati; to his benefit and duty to keep separate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bakasht malik neutral re raiyati status.

court_reasoning.text: No conflict in records; bakasht entry does not negate raiyati; no res judicata issue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question mixed law/fact; High Court could review.

court_reasoning.text: Civil court must ignore invalid transfers under s.27(2); not barred by s.27(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.27(2) obliges courts to recognize invalidity.

holdings.text: Raiyati interest did not merge in proprietary interest; continued to exist.
1935 sale void with respect to raiyati interest; only right to receive rent passed.
Civil courts have jurisdiction to declare invalid transfers under s.27 Reg.III 1872.

precedents_cited.relevance: Doctrine of merger does not apply to mofussil lands; zamindar can hold patni.
Merger if conduct shows no intention to keep interests distinct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Kissen Dutt Ram v. Raja Mumtaz Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Possibility of merger of resumable birt in superior interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surja Narain Mandal v. Nand Lall Sinha
Promotha Nath Roy v. Kishore Lal Sinha
Dakshavani Dasi v. Amrita Lal Ghosh

precedents_cited.relevance: Similar view indicated by Patna HC.
Presumption against merger if duty/interest to keep separate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarda Devi v. Ram Louchan Bhagat
precedents_cited.relevance: s.27 does not prohibit landlord transferring interest in raiyati holding; but does not pass raiyati interest.
Later entry prevails in specific facts; bakasht not always negation of raiyati.

statutes_cited.name: Regulation III of 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits transfer of raiyati interest unless recorded; courts must ignore invalid transfers; DC eviction power not exclusive.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory merger provisions; no application here.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Tenancy Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory merger provisions; extended to Bihar, no application here.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court: raiyati interest continued unmerged; 1935 sale void as to raiyati interest, valid only for right to receive rent.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that sale void w.r.t. raiyati interest; implied restoration of possession/title to raiyati interest.

key_quotes.text: "If a raiyat of lands in the District of Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlords interests, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming a superior landlord?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No transfer by a raiyat of his right in his holding... shall be valid unless the right to transfer has been recorded in the record of rights..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.27(1) Reg.III 1872, central to inalienability.

key_quotes.text: "Our conclusion therefore is that the raiyati interest did not merge in the proprietary interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the sale of May 15, 1935 was void with respect to the raiyati interest and only the right to receive rent passed by this sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
